newsitem.title: USA: CME lumber ends up sharply to limit on rising cash.
newsitem.headline: CME lumber ends up sharply to limit on rising cash.

text.p: Reports of further advances in cash lumber prices kept CME lumber futures sharply higher to limit up at the close with all but distant November posting new contract highs.

Futures ended $18.80 to $4.00 per thousand board feet higher with limitless January up most at $443.50 per tbf after setting a new high of $450.50 during the day. March finished up the $10.00 limit at a new high of $427.30 per tbf.
Futures rallied after falling from initial gains on profit taking following the break in financials. Cash sources said spruce prices were rising.
"Some (buyers) are coming back to the market that have been out of the market for two or three weeks," said Neil Schmaedick, Smith Barney Forest Products analyst.

Cash sources said there were mills asking as high as $422 for spruce. This was well above the last official quote of $392 for spruce last Friday. Wholesalers and dealers were short of lumber while production was still minimal due to the holidays and poor weather in the Northwest, they said.
In lumber options, March traded synthetically $2.00 to $3.00 higher on spreads, pit sources added.
